Article Role of Y2O3 in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol Ziguo Cai a Xuefeng Yu a Penglong Wang b Huifang Wu c Ruifeng Chong b Limin Ren c Tao Hu c Xiang Wang a * a State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals School of Chemical Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China b College of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences, Henan University, Kaifeng 475004, Henan, China College of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences Henan University Kaifeng Henan 475004 China College of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences, Henan University, Kaifeng 475004, Henan, China c School of Chemistry, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China School of Chemistry Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 China School of Chemistry, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China * Corresponding author. CuZn-based catalyst is an attractive catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation, but it early deactivates and its methanol yield still needs to improve. In this study, Y2O3 was introduced to Cu/ZnO using a one-pot hydrothermal method, and exhibits a synergistic effect of ZnO and Y2O3 on enhancing methanol yield and the stability. We found that the interaction between Y2O3 and ZnO results in abundant oxygen vacancies formation, thereby enhancing CO2 adsorption and activation. Kinetic analysis and in situ DRIFTS suggest that RWGS forming CO and methanol formation compete for a mutual intermediate HCOO*, and the introduction of Y2O3 to Cu/ZnO raises the energy barrier for the CO formation but lowers that for methanol formation, thus enhancing the methanol yield on Cu/ZnO/Y2O3. Graphical Abstract The synergy between ZnO and Y2O3 in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst improves the dispersion of Cu species and promotes the generation of oxygen vacancy, thereby enhancing methanol yield. Keywords Methanol yield Oxygen vacancies Kinetics Fourier transformed infrared Intermediate 1 Introduction Hydrogenation of carbon dioxide has garnered significant attention as it is one of attractive strategies in carbon capture utilization and storage (CCUS) [ 1–5 ]. One of the products from CO2 hydrogenation with a specific catalyst could be methanol, which serves not only as a fuel but also as a fundamental raw material for producing high-value chemicals, including lower olefins, gasoline, aromatics, and the like [ 6–8 ]. CuZn-based catalyst is considered a promising catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation in practice due to low cost and high activity [ 9–11 ]. However, it exhibits lower methanol selectivity due to the competitive reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction and early deactivation. The early deactivation is mainly attributed to the sintering of the ZnO and Cu particles in the presence of water, which is formed in CO2 hydrogenation [ 12–14 ]. To address these challenges, Song et al. [ 15 ] incorporated Al2O3 into ZnO to form a spinel ZnAl2O4 structure for stabilizing the Zn-containing support, resulting in an enhanced CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity for the Cu/ZnAl2O4 catalyst. Cored et al. [ 16 ] found that doping Ga3+ in the lattice of ZnO alters its local electronic structure in a Cu/ZnO/Ga2O3 catalyst, thus inhibiting the RWGS reaction and promoting methanol selectivity. Singh et al. [ 17 ] doped CeO2 into CuZnO catalysts, which not only improved the dispersion of Cu but also generated abundant oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface, thus improving the methanol selectivity and CO2 conversion. The introduction of Y2O3 to Cu/ZnO catalyst results in an enhancement of methanol yield, which is close to the performance of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst [ 18 ]. Gao et al. [ 19,20 ] found the improved activity of Cu/ZnO catalyst is due to the enhanced dispersion of Cu particles, caused by the introduction of Y2O3. However, Qi et al. [ 21 ] found that only a slight reduction in Cu size is observed when introducing Y2O3 into CuZn-based catalysts, they attributed the enhancement of activity to the reduced ZnO size caused by Y2O3 introduction. Therefore, the impact of Y2O3 introduction on the Cu/ZnO catalyst as well as the reaction remains unclear. In this study, we prepared a Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst, which shows a synergistic effect of ZnO and Y2O3 supports, showing a higher methanol yield than Cu/ZnO and Cu/Y2O3. We found that the interaction between Y2O3 and ZnO not only improves the dispersion of Cu species, but also promotes the generation of oxygen vacancy (Ov) on the catalyst surface. The formation of Ov enhances CO2 adsorption and activation, thereby enhancing CO2 conversion via the formate route to methanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts In the synthesis of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts, the ratio of ZnO to Y2O3 was varied at 13:1, 4:1, 2:1, 1:1 in weight, and the Cu loading was maintained at 30 wt% while keeping the support ZnO and Y2O3 total at 70 wt%. In a typical synthesis of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst with the ratio of ZnO to Y2O3 at 2:1, the 1.289 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 1.858 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, and 0.479 g of Y(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water to form solution A. The 1.249 g of NaOH was dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water to form solution B, and 0.579 g of Na2CO3 was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water to form solution C. After stirring the solutions at 25 °C for 20 min, solutions A and B were slowly added to solution C simultaneously. The resulted mixed solution was stirred at 25 °C for 30 min and then transferred to a hydrothermal autoclave. The suspension was hydrothermally treated at 90 °C for 24 h, then cooled to room temperature and collected by centrifugation. The product was washed six times with deionized water and dried at 80 °C overnight. The dried product was calcined at 450 °C for 4 h (heating rate of 1 °C min–1) named as CuZn-ox, CuZnY-13-ox, CuZnY-4-ox, CuZnY-2-ox, CuZnY-1-ox and CuY-ox. All samples were pretreated at 300 °C in a H2 flow with a rate of 30 mL min–1 for 2 h before use for CO2 hydrogenation, and labelled as CuZn, CuZnY-13, CuZnY-4, CuZnY-2, CuZnY-1 and CuY. In addition, we synthesized a series of CuZnY catalysts with a 5% Cu loading by following the same synthesis method, simply reducing the Cu loading from 30% to 5%, while keeping all other conditions unchanged. 2.2 Catalyst evaluation The CO2 hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor. Typically, 0.2 g of catalysts (40–60 mesh) were mixed with 0.4 g of SiC and then loaded into the reactor. A mixed gas CO2/H2/Ar with a ratio of 3:1:1 was injected into the reactor at a flow rate 30 mL min–1. The reactor pressure was maintained at 3 MPa and the gas hour space velocity (GHSV) was maintained at 9000 mL gcat. –1 h–1. The effluent gaseous product was kept at 110 °C to avoid condensation. The product was analyzed using a PANNA A60 on-line gas chromatograph and equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The chromatographic column consisted of a 5 Å molecular sieve column and an HQ column. CO2 conversion (X CO2), CH3OH selectivity (S CH3OH), CO selectivity (S CO), CH3OH space-time yield (STY), CO STY and carbon balance (E c) were calculated as follows: X CO2 = (n CO2,in – n CO2,out)/n CO2,in × 100% S CH3OH = n CH3OH/(n CO + n CH3OH) × 100% S CO = n CO/(n CO + n CH3OH) × 100% CH3OH STY (gCH3OH kgcat. –1 h–1) = n CO2,in × X CO2 × S CH3OH × 32 × 1000/mcat. CO STY (gCO kgcat. –1 h–1) = n CO2,in × X CO2 × S CO × 28 × 1000/mcat. Ec (%) = (n CO2,out + n CH3OH + n CO)/n CO2,in × 100% where n CO2,in and n CO2,out denote the molar flow rates of CO2 in the feed and tail gases, n CH3OH and n CO denote the molar flow rates in the tail gas, and m Cat. denotes the mass of the catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Scanning electron microscope (SEM) with a model number of JSM-7610F from Nippon Electron Co was employed to study the morphology of the catalysts. Elemental distribution on the catalyst surface was analyzed through energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) element mapping. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Smart Lab 9 kW X-ray diffractometer. The operating conditions were 45 kV, 200 mA, a scanning range of 20°–80°, a scanning speed of 10°min–1, and a step size of 0.02°. Cu average particle size (d Cu) calculated from Cu (111) peak XRD by Debye-Scherrer formula. D = Kλ/βcosθ where D denotes the grain size (nm), K denotes Scherrer’s constant (K = 0.89), λ is the X-ray wavelength, for Cu Ka take 0.15406 nm, β denotes the full width at half maximum (FWHM), and θ is the diffraction angle. Raman spectroscopy was performed using a Witec Confocal Micro Raman Spectrometer, employing a diode-pumped solid-state laser with a wavelength of 532 nm as the light source. The sampling time for each measurement was set to 90 s. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 physisorption instrument. Prior to testing, the catalysts were degassed under vacuum at 120 °C for 6 h and subsequently evaluated at liquid nitrogen temperature (–196 °C). The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the pore size distribution was determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted on a chemisorption instrument. A sample of 50 mg of calcined oxide was placed in a U-tube and pretreated in an argon atmosphere (30 mL min–1) at 150 °C for 30 min. The temperature was then reduced to room temperature, followed by the introduction of a 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min–1). The temperature was ramped from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1, with hydrogen consumption recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was tested on a chemisorption instrument. 100 mg of pre-reduced catalyst was weighed and loaded into a U-tube, which was first reduced in situ at 300 °C in 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min–1) for 1 h. After that, it was switched to Ar (30 mL min–1) atmosphere and continued to purge for 2 h to make sure that the H2 on the surface of the catalyst was purged clean. After cooling to 50 °C, CO2 gas was absorbed in 10% CO2/Ar (30 mL min–1) atmosphere for 1h, and then switched to Ar atmosphere for further purging for 30 min. The temperature was increased from 50 to 800 °C (heating rate 10 °C min–1), and the amount of CO2 desorption was recorded by TCD. H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) was tested on a chemisorption instrument. 100 mg of pre-reduced catalyst was weighed and loaded into a U-tube, which was first reduced in situ at 300 °C in 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min–1) for 30 min. After that, it was switched to Ar (30 mL min–1) atmosphere and continued to purge for 30 min. After cooling to 50 °C, H2 gas was absorbed in 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min–1) atmosphere for 1h, and then switched to Ar atmosphere for further purging for 30 min. The temperature was increased from 50 to 800 °C (heating rate 10 °C min–1), and the amount of H2 desorption was recorded by mass spectrometry. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Shimadzu KRATOS AXIS SUPRA X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. The rays were Al Kα , and all catalyst XPS spectra were charge corrected using the C 1s binding energy (284.6 eV). N2O titration experiments were used to measure the dispersion (D Cu) and average particle size (d Cu) of Cu. First, 30 mg of the oxide was loaded into a chemisorption instrument U-tube and treated with Ar (30 mL min–1) at 300 °C for 30 min. Then cool down to room temperature at 300 °C for the first reduction with 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min–1) gas and record the corresponding H2 consumption as X 1 (mol H2 gcat.–1). Then after cooling down to 50 °C and purging with Ar for 30 min, N2O (30 mL min–1) atmosphere was introduced for 1 h to ensure that the surface exposed Cu was completely oxidized to Cu2O. Afterwards, after purging with Ar for 30 min, 10% H2/Ar was introduced to raise the temperature to 300 °C for the second reduction, and the corresponding H2 consumption was recorded as X 2 (mol H2 gcat.–1). The dispersion (D Cu) and average particle size (d Cu, assuming a spherical shape of the Cu particles) of Cu were calculated from the following equations: D cu (%) = 2X 2/X 1 × 100% d cu (nm) = 104/D cu(%) The apparent activation energy and reaction orders for methanol formation were calculated by the following equations. (1) r CH3OH/CO = Ae(–Ea/RT) (2) lnr CH3OH/CO = lnA–E a/RT (3) r CH3OH = kP m CO2 Pn H2 (4) lnr CH3OH = lnk + mlnP CO2 + nlnP H2 where the plot of lnr CH3OH/CO against 1/T is linear and the slope –E a/R × (–R) is the apparent activation energy of CH3OH or CO as expressed in Eq. (2). The plot of lnr CH3OH against lnP CO2 or lnP H2 is linear and the slope corresponds to the reaction order as expressed in Eq. (4). In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were carried out on NCOLET iS50R FT-IR spectrometer. CuZnY-2-ox with 5% Cu loading and the same synthesis procedure was selected as a representative. The sample was reduced with pure H2 (20 mL min–1) at 300 °C for 2 h and cooled to 240 °C to collect background spectra. Then, the atmosphere was switched to 75% H2/25% CO2 (20 mL min–1) and the spectral data were recorded at different times. After 60 min of reaction, the atmosphere was switched to H2 atmosphere and the spectral data were recorded at different times. In addition, CO2 adsorption tests were carried out and spectral data were recorded by switching to 25% CO2/Ar (20 mL min–1) atmosphere after 1 h purge with Ar. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 in CO2 hydrogenation Figs. 1(a) , (b) shows the performance of the CuZnY-2 catalyst with temperature varying in the range of 200–260 °C. Only methanol and CO are detected as products over this catalyst. As the temperature increases from 200 to 260 °C, CO2 conversion rises from 2.7% to 13.4%, while methanol selectivity decreases from 88.8% to 38.2%. Notably, the STY of methanol increases, reaching a maximum of 140 gCH3OH kgcat. –1 h–1 at 240 °C, after which it slightly declines with further temperature increases. However, the CO STY increases continuously from 6.7 to 186.8 gco kgcat. –1 h–1. These results suggest that the formation of CH₃OH and CO may involve a mutual intermediate species, leading to competition between the two pathways. At lower temperatures, the synthesis of methanol predominates, whereas the production of CO is favored at elevated temperatures. The effect of the introduction of Y2O3 on the catalytic performance is investigated and the result is shown in Figs. 1(c), (d). For the CuZn catalyst, the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity are 4.3% and 63.8%, respectively, leading to CH3OH STY and CO STY at 70.8 gCH3OH kgcat. –1 h–1 and 35.1 gCO kgcat. –1 h–1 under a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 9000 mL gcat –1 h–1. Upon Y2O3 addition to Cu/ZnO, the CO2 conversion and methanol STY increase significantly, and reach maximums of 9.3% and 140.0 gCH3OH kgcat. –1 h–1, respectively, as the weight ratio of ZnO to Y2O3 is 2:1. Further increases in Y2O3 loading slightly decreases CO2 conversion but maintains the selectivity of methanol, leading to a slight decrease in methanol STY. The CO STY shows an increasing trend, rising from 52.7 gCO kgcat. –1 h–1 to 87.7 gCO kgcat. –1 h–1. For the CuY catalyst, the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity are 4.8% and 51.5%, respectively, resulting in a CH3OH STY at 64.2 gCH3OH kgcat. –1 h–1 and a CO STY at 52.8 gCO kgcat. –1 h–1 under the same GHSV. Its performance is very similar with CuZn catalyst, but much lower than CuZnY-2 catalysts. In addition, as shown in Figs. S1(a), (b), we tested the performance of the catalysts with Cu loading of 5% (all other synthesis conditions remained unchanged, and only the 30% Cu loading is reduced to 5%). The performance trend of the catalysts with 5% Cu loading is consistent with that of the catalysts with 30% Cu loading. The CuZnY-2 still the best catalyst in these catalysts regarding methanol yield. Note that the loading of Cu, which was considered as active site for methanol generation [ 22 ], maintained at 30% in all catalysts, so the enhancement in methanol synthesis could be caused by the synergistic effect of ZnO and Y2O3. As shown in Table S1, the Carbon balance (E c) values of all catalysts are approximately above 95%, which is in a reasonable range indicating no carbon loss [ 23 ]. 3.2 Effects of introduction Y2O3 on the structure of support The morphology of the catalysts was investigated using SEM, as illustrated in Fig. 2 . The CuZn catalyst exhibits a distinct flower-like morphology (Fig. 2(a)), while the CuY catalyst displays a flocculent morphology (Fig. 2(b)). Notably, upon the introduction of Y2O3 into the Cu/ZnO, the CuZnY-2 catalyst presents a spherical morphology (Figs. 2(c) and (d)) with an average diameter of approximately 3 μm. EDS element mapping (Figs. 2(e)–(h)) reveals a uniform distribution of Cu, Zn, Y, and O within the catalyst. This result indicate that the Y2O3 may be incorporated into the support of ZnO. Although CuZnY-2 catalyst presents a spherical morphology, it consists of agglomerated particles. Therefore, we examined the effect of Y2O3 on the specific surface area of the catalyst, and listed the data in Table S2. The specific surface area of the CuZn catalyst is 6 m2 g–1. When Y2O3 is introduced into Cu/ZnO, the specific surface area of the catalyst gradually increases with the amount of Y2O3 added. However, the methanol yield shows a trend of increasing and then decreasing. In particular, the CuZnY-2, the highest methanol yield catalyst, exhibits a specific surface area at 22 m2 g–1, which is a medium value in all catalysts. This suggests that the specific surface area is not the primary factor contributing to the enhanced activity of the CuZnY-2 catalysts. The phase structures of the catalysts are analyzed using XRD as shown in Fig. 3(a) . For the CuZn catalyst, the diffraction peaks observed at 31.77°, 34.42°, 36.25°, 47.54°, 56.60°, 62.86°, 66.38°, 67.96°, 69.10°, 72.56°, and 76.95° correspond to ZnO (PDF#36-1451) [ 24,25 ]. The peaks at 43.30°, 50.43°, and 74.13° are attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Cu (PDF# 04-0836) [ 13,26 ]. Besides of these peaks, no other diffraction peaks are observed. For the CuY catalysts, only the diffraction peaks of metal Cu are observed, and no diffraction peaks of Y2O3 are observed. For the CuZnY-2 catalyst, the diffraction peaks of metal Cu and ZnO are observed, and no diffraction peaks of Y2O3 are observed either. This suggests that Y2O3 may be highly dispersed, which agrees well with the results of EDS shown in Fig. 2(g). Notably, the FWHM of the Cu diffraction peaks in the CuZnY-2 catalyst is significantly increased compared to the CuZn catalyst. In addition, as shown in Table S3, we calculated the average particle sizes of metal Cu on CuZn, CuZnY-2 and CuY catalysts to be 21, 11, and 14 nm, respectively, using the Debye-Scherrer formula. These results are also closely aligned with the average particle size of Cu calculated from the N2O titration experiments. This indicates that the synergistic effect between Y2O3 and ZnO effectively enhances the dispersion of Cu. Compared with XRD characterization, Raman spectroscopy is more sensitive to the surface region of the catalyst [ 27,28 ]. As shown in Fig. S2, for the CuZn-ox, the Raman shifts at 288 and 353 cm–1 are attributed to the vibration of Cu–O [ 29–31 ], while the peaks at 320, 425 and 567 cm–1 are ascribed to the vibration of Zn-O [ 31,32 ]. For the CuY-ox, the vibration peak of Cu-O can be observed at 355 cm–1, and the peak at 508 cm–1 is attributed to Cu2O [ 10,33 ]. For CuZnY-2-ox, only the vibration peaks of Zn–O are observed and no vibration peaks of Cu–O are observed, indicating that CuO is highly dispersed on the catalyst surface. In addition, no peaks corresponding to Y2O3 are observed for CuY-ox and CuZnY-2-ox, indicating that Y2O3 is highly dispersed. This finding is consistent with the results obtained from XRD analysis. It is noteworthy that the ZnO vibration peaks of CuZn-ox show a red shift (320 and 425 cm–1) compared to ZnO (329 and 437 cm–1), which may be caused by ZnO lattice distortion due to Cu doping into the ZnO lattice. Wen et al. [ 34 ] and Xue et al. [ 35 ] observed a similar phenomenon in their Raman spectroscopy studies, attributing it to ZnO lattice distortion caused by Cu doping. Additionally, the peaks for ZnO in the CuZnY-2-ox exhibit a blue shift (from 320 to 328 cm–1, and from 425 to 435 cm–1) compared to calcined CuZn-ox, aligning more closely with the peaks of ZnO. This may be attributed to the interaction between ZnO and Y2O3, which inhibits Cu doping into the ZnO lattice. This is further supported by the observation that the ZnO peaks in the ZnY-ox show no significant changes compared to ZnO. As shown in Fig. 3(b), after the reduction of CuZn-ox, the ZnO peaks on the CuZn catalyst exhibit no significant changes, and no CuO peaks are observed, indicating that CuO is completely reduced to metallic Cu. When CuY-ox is reduced, only the Cu2O peak is observed on the CuY catalyst. Interestingly, after the reduction of CuZnY-2-ox, the ZnO peaks for the CuZnY-2 catalyst shift to a reverse direction, showing a red shift to 319 and to 423 cm–1. This may be caused by oxygen vacancy (Ov) generation [ 36 ]. A similar phenomenon was observed by Yan et al. [ 37 ] with a Cu/CeO2/ZrO2 catalyst, where the Raman peak of CeO2 exhibited a red shift when the catalyst was reduced by H2 and attributed it to be caused by Ov generation. Therefore, we assume that the Ov may form when reducing the CuZnY-2-ox to prepare the CuZnY-2 catalyst. To test our hypothesis, we re-oxidized the CuZnY-2 catalyst at 300 °C in air, and showed its Raman spectrum with a label as CuZnY-2-ro in Fig. 3(c). The Raman peaks of ZnO (326 and 432 cm–1) shift back to 328 and 435 cm–1. Interestingly, when CuZnY-2-ro is subsequently reduced again, the Raman peaks of ZnO re-shifts back to the position at 320 and 424 cm–1). The reversible shift of the Raman peak due to the band of Zn–O further confirms that the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies caused by introduction of Y2O3. For the XPS O 1s spectra of CuZn, CuZnY-2 and CuY catalyst (Fig. 3(d)), the peak at about 529.8 eV is attributed to the lattice oxygen (OL), the peak at about 531.3 eV is ascribed to the surface adsorbed oxygen (OA), and the peak at about 532.5 eV is assigned to the adsorbed water molecules and hydroxyl groups (OW) species [ 38,39 ]. The ratio of relative intensities of oxygen species, i.e. OA/Ototal (Ototal = OL + OA + OW), is usually used as a descriptor to compare the abundance of oxygen vacancy [ 40,41 ]. As listed in Table S4, the ratios for the three catalysts are 48.8% (CuZn), 59.4% (CuZnY-2) and 35.7% (CuY), respectively. Obviously, the CuZnY-2 catalyst has abundant oxygen vacancies compared to CuZn catalyst, which further confirms that the introduction of Y2O3 can form more Ov on the catalyst surface. 3.3 Effect of the introduction of Y2O3 on Cu species The reduction of Cu species and their interaction with support are investigated by H2-TPR as shown in Fig. 4(a) . For CuZn-ox, the reduction peak at 210 °C is attributed to the reduction of CuO on ZnO support [ 18,42 ]. For CuY-ox, the reduction peak of CuO on Y2O3 shifts to higher temperature at 236 °C compared to that on CnZn-ox, indicating a stronger interaction between Cu and Y2O3 compared to Cu and ZnO. When Y2O3 is introduced to Cu/ZnO, two reduction peaks are observed. One at 210 °C is identical to that of CuZn-ox, which corresponds to the reduction of CuO contacting ZnO. However, the other one at 246 °C is significantly higher than that of CuZn-ox and CuY-ox, indicating a strong interaction between Cu species and ZnO/Y2O3 support. Zhu et al. [ 43 ] found that the interaction between Cu and CeO2 is significantly stronger than that between Cu and ZnO, and this strong interaction can effectively improve the dispersion of Cu. Therefore, the strong interaction of Cu with ZnO/Y2O3 in the CuZnY-2 catalyst is one of the reasons for the improved dispersion of Cu. This is consistent with the results of N2O titration experiments for the dispersion of Cu (Table S3). For the Cu 2p XPS spectra of the catalyst (Fig. 4(b)), the peak at about 932.5 eV is attributed to the Cu0 species [ 44 ]. This indicates that the surface Cu2+ of the three catalysts has been essentially reduced to Cu0 species. Since the difficulty in distinguishing the surface Cu0 and Cu+ species in Cu 2p XPS. We employed Auger electron spectroscopy to study the Cu in these catalysts. As shown in Fig. S3, the peaks at about 569.2 and 573.1 eV are attributed to Cu0 and Cu+ species, respectively [ 45 ]. For CuZn and CuZnY-2 catalysts, the peak at about 576.5 eV is attributed to Zn L3M23M45(3P) [ 46 ]. The proportion of Cu0 species in the catalyst surface is calculated using the ratio of peak areas as listed in Table S4. For the three catalysts, the proportion of Cu0 species is about 70%, which indicates that the surface of the three catalysts is mainly dominated by the presence of Cu0 species. 3.4 Kinetics analysis The Arrhenius plots for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over these catalysts are shown in Fig. 5(a) . The apparent activation energy for methanol formation (E aCH3OH) on CuZn and CuY catalysts are 88 and 69 kJ mol–1, respectively, and that on CuZnY-2 catalyst is 65 kJ mol–1, very similar to that on CuY catalyst. However, unlike the similarity of activation energy for methanol formation on CuZnY-2 and CuY, the apparent activation energy for CO formation (E aCO) on CnZnY-2 is about 137 kJ mol–1 (Fig. 5(b)), which is closer to that on CuZn (135 kJ mol–1), and much higher than that on CuY (112.0 kJ mol–1). By comparing activation energies for CO formation and methanol formation over these three catalysts, the biggest gap can be figured out (ΔE a = E aCO – E aCH3OH) about 72 kJ mol–1 on CuZnY-2 catalyst, over 47 kJ mol–1 on CuZn and 43 kJ mol–1 on CuY. These results suggest that the introduction of Y2O3 increases the energy barrier for the CO formation but decreases that for methanol formation. Fig. 5(c) show that the H2 reaction orders for methanol formation on the CuZn, CuZnY-2 and CuY catalysts are 0.8, 0.9 and 1.1, respectively. In Fig. 5(d), the CO2 reaction orders for methanol generation on the CuZn, CuZnY-2, and CuY catalysts are 0.2, 0.1, and 0.1, respectively. For all three catalysts, it can be observed that the H2 reaction order is close to 1, and the CO2 reaction order is close to 0. This shows that there is no significant difference in the activation of H2 or CO2 by the three catalysts. The adsorption capacity of the catalyst for H2 was investigated using H2-TPD, as shown in Fig. S4. The peak at about 105 °C is attributed to adsorption of H species on the surface Cu sites [ 45 ]. The broad peak at about 419 °C is attributed to strong adsorption of H species on the support [ 47 ]. The adsorption capacity of the three catalysts for H2 is estimated by the peak area using the signal from mass spectrometry. and the results are shown in Table S5. The CuZn catalyst has the strongest H2 adsorption capacity, the CuZnY catalyst has a moderate H2 adsorption capacity, and the CuY catalyst has the weakest H2 adsorption capacity. This suggests that Y2O3 introduction may decrease the H2 adsorption capacity on the catalyst surface. This result agrees well with the slight increasing trend for H2 reaction order as the Y2O3 is added to the catalyst. The CO2-TPD was performed to further investigate the interaction between CO2 and the catalysts (Fig. 6(a) ). The desorption peaks at 50–200 °C are attributed to weak basic sites, the desorption peaks at 200–400 °C are ascribed to moderate basic sites, and the desorption peaks at > 400 °C are assigned to strong basic sites [ 11,48,49 ]. Generally, CO2 species adsorbed at moderate basic sites are more conducive to reacting with H species on the catalyst surface, while those at weak basic sites are easy to desorb and at strong basic sites are difficult to desorb blocking the active sites [ 48 ]. Furthermore, excessive accumulation of CO2 species on the catalyst surface can block active sites, which is also unfavorable for methanol production [ 50,51 ]. Therefore, the proportion of moderate basic sites is calculated using the areas of the desorption peaks and is shown in Fig. 6(b). The proportion of moderate basic sites on the CuZn catalyst is 23.9%, while the CuY catalyst exhibits almost no moderate basic sites. However, upon introducing Y2O3 into Cu/ZnO, the proportion of moderate basic sites on the CuZnY-2 catalyst increases to 42.3%, which is significantly higher than that on the CuZn catalyst. Previous studies have shown that the number of moderate basic sites is closely related to the number of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [ 11,48 ]. Therefore, we speculate that the interaction between ZnO and Y2O3 promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, thereby enhancing CO2 adsorption and activation. This result was also confirmed by Wang et al. [ 22 ], they found that the interaction between ZnO and ZrO2 on Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts promoted the generation of oxygen vacancies, which enhanced CO2 adsorption and activation. 3.5 Reaction intermediates The intermediates formed during the interaction of CO2 with CuZnY-2 (5% Cu loading) catalyst at 240 °C was investigated by in situ DRIFTS, and the spectra is shown in Fig. 7 . When the feed gas was switched from Ar to CO2, the three peaks at 1578, 1335 and 1289 cm–1 appear with time on stream, and they are ascribed to bidentate carbonate species [ 52,53 ]. Besides, the minor peaks at 1221 and 1622 cm–1 are also observed, and they are attributed to bidentate bicarbonate species [ 52 ]. However, we found the intermediates formed in CO2 are very different from that formed in CO2 with H2. As shown in Fig. 8(a) , the two main peaks at 1374 and 1590 cm–1 gradually grow up when the catalyst is placed in the flow gas of CO2+H2, and they are attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric O=C=O stretching vibrations of bidentate formate (HCOO*) species [ 54 ]. This is also confirmed by the growing peaks at 1388 and 2883 cm–1, which are ascribed to the vibrations of C–H in bidentate formate (HCOO*) species [ 6,54 ]. However, if we look at the first few spectra, we can see the peaks at 1289 cm–1 ascribed to the bidentate carbonate species, but it disappears after 5 min of reaction as formate species accumulates over time. This suggests that bidentate carbonate species may react with H species to form formate, which agrees well with the results observed on Cu-ZnO-ZrO2 catalysts [ 22 ]. As the formate grows up, another small peaks at 2828 cm–1 can be observed, and they are attributed to methoxy species (CH3O*) [ 22,53 ]. To clear observe the trend, the integrated intensity of peak due to formate (2883 cm–1) and methoxy (2828 cm–1) species are analyzed with time shown in Fig. 8(b). It is observed that methoxy species displayed an increasing trend alongside the continuous accumulation of formate species. These results indicate that formate could be the intermediates to methoxy, which is in line with the result observed by inverse ZrO2/Cu catalyst [ 55 ]. When the feed gas is switched from CO2 + H2 to H2, the integrated intensity of formate decreased with time, while that for methoxy increases (Figs. 8(c), (d)). This result indicates that the formate react with H faster than the methoxy species hydrogenates to methanol in H2. Additionally, the results of the kinetic analysis reveal that the apparent activation energy for methanol formation (E aCH3OH = 65 kJ mol–1) over the CuZnY-2 catalyst is significantly lower than that for CO generation (EaCO = 137 kJ mol–1). This indicates that CO is not an intermediate in the methanol generation process. Therefore, formate is believed as the intermediate in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Wang et al. [ 22 ] found that CO2 adsorbed on ZnO and ZrO2 supports with dissociated H2 from Cu species first formed carbonate species. These carbonate species continued to hydrogenate to produce formate species. Finally, the formate species were hydrogenated to form methoxy and methanol. A similar phenomenon was observed by Han et al. on Cu@ZrO2 catalysts, where CO2 adsorption first formed carbonate species. These carbonate species then continued to hydrogenate to form formate and methoxy [ 56 ]. Based on the previous reports and the observation in in situ DRIFTS experiments, the reaction pathway for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on the CuZnY-2 catalyst can be further inferred (Fig. 8(e)). Initially, CO2 adsorbs to form bidentate carbonate species, which then react with H species dissociated from Cu0 to produce formate species (HCOO*). Subsequently, the formate species react with H species to generate methoxy species (CH3O*). Finally, the methoxy species continue to react with H species to form methanol. Therefore, CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over CuZnY-2 catalyst predominantly follows the formate pathway. It is important to emphasize that our in situ DRIFTS was conducted under ambient conditions, while the reaction was performed at 3 MPa. The difference in pressure can result in different reaction rates to methanol, thus impacting the surface chemistry and mechanism derived from the ambient pressure IR study. To more accurately identify the reaction mechanism of the catalyst, it is necessary to develop advanced operando IR techniques for conducting experiments under relevant operating conditions. 3.6 Stability It is well known that CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is a structure-sensitive reaction, making the maintenance of catalyst structural stability during the reaction critical for optimizing methanol yield. As shown in Fig. 9 , the stability of the CuZnY-2 catalyst is evaluated over a 100-h reaction period. No significant loss of CO2 conversion is observed on CuZnY-2, and the methanol STY remains stable. In contrast, a marked decrease in methanol STY is noted for the CuZn catalyst. The XRD and Raman spectroscopy results of the CuZnY-2-used (after 100 hours reaction) catalyst shown in Figs. S5 and S6 do not show significant changes compared to those of the fresh CuZnY-2 catalyst. Furthermore, the SEM images of the CuZnY-2-used in Figs. S7(a), (b) show that the catalysts maintain the same spherical morphology as the fresh CuZnY-2 (Figs. 2(c) and (d)) catalyst. These results demonstrate the good stability of the CuZnY-2 catalyst during the reaction. 4 Conclusions The support ZnO/Y2O3 exhibits a synergy effect on promoting methanol yield in CO2 hydrogenation reaction compared to ZnO or Y2O3 single-oxide-supported Cu catalyst. This synergy not only improves the dispersion of Cu but also promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies (Ov) in ZnO, where Ov enhance CO2 adsorption and activation. Kinetic analyses combined with in situ DRIFTS experiments reveal that the CO is not the intermediate for the methanol formation, but RWGS forming CO and methanol formation compete for the species HCOO*, and the introduction of Y2O3 to Cu/ZnO increases the energy barrier for the CO formation but decreases that for methanol formation, which makes methanol pathway more favorable for the mutual HCOO* species when compared to Cu/ZnO and Cu/Y2O3 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: CuZn-based catalyst is an attractive catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation, but it early deactivates and its methanol yield still needs to improve. In this study, Y2O3 was introduced to Cu/ZnO using a one-pot hydrothermal method, and exhibits a synergistic effect of ZnO and Y2O3 on enhancing methanol yield and the stability. We found that the interaction between Y2O3 and ZnO results in abundant oxygen vacancies formation, thereby enhancing CO2 adsorption and activation. Kinetic analysis and in situ DRIFTS suggest that RWGS forming CO and methanol formation compete for a mutual intermediate HCOO*, and the introduction of Y2O3 to Cu/ZnO raises the energy barrier for the CO formation but lowers that for methanol formation, thus enhancing the methanol yield on Cu/ZnO/Y2O3.

coredata.dc:title: Role of Y2O3 in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol
